definition: Jinggang Mountains, in the Jiangxi-Hunan border region
Jinggangshan county level city in Ji'an 吉安, Jiangxi
Jing, one of the 28 constellations of Chinese astronomy/surname Jing
a well/CL:口[kou3]/neat/orderly
ridge/mound
mountain/hill/anything that resembles a mountain/CL:座[zuo4]/bundled straw in which silkworms spin cocoons/gable
surname Shan
Jinggangshan county level city in Ji'an 吉安, Jiangxi

sentences.english: Educational Jinggangshan red resources are a specific form of Jinggangshan Red Resources.
sentences.chinese: 井岡山紅色資源是優質教育資源。

sentences.english: In this summer vacation, they visited Jin Gang mountain.
sentences.chinese: 今年暑假，他們還一起遊覽了井岡山。

sentences.english: Jing Gang and has an altitude of 820 meters.
sentences.chinese: 它位於井岡山風景區的中部，海拔820米。

sentences.english: From Wanan eighty revolutionary peasants returned with our men to the Chingkang Mountains and were organized as the Wanan Red Guards.
sentences.chinese: 有八十個革命農民跟隨到井岡山，組織萬安赤衛隊。

sentences.english: The address is No. 5 Jing Gang Shan Street, Nanchang City, Jiangxi Province. Is that right?
sentences.chinese: 地址是江西省南昌市井岡山大道5號，對嗎？

sentences.english: The Jinggang Mountains stand where the boundaries of four counties meet.
The Red Army made Jinggangshan the base for the revolution.
sentences.chinese: 紅軍把井岡山作爲革命根據地。

sentences.english: Waterfall group in 5-Dragon Pools consists 5 waterfalls.
sentences.chinese: 井岡山五龍潭瀑布羣由5個瀑布組成。

sentences.english: The fourth part serves as the research work on Jinggang Mountain tourism cluster.
sentences.chinese: 第四部分爲井岡山旅遊產業集羣化發展實證研究。

sentences.english: Jinggangshan unselfish dedication spirit is the concentrated reflection of Marxist view of Value.
sentences.chinese: 井岡山無私奉獻精神是馬克思主義價值觀的集中體現。

definition: Nanchang Uprising, 1st August 1927, the beginning of military revolt by the Communists in the Chinese Civil War
Autumn Harvest Uprising (1927), insurrection in Hunan and Jiangxi provinces led by Mao Zedong

Peng Dehuai (1898-1974), top communist general, subsequently politician and politburo member, disgraced after attacking Mao's failed policies in 1959, and died after extensive persecution during the Cultural Revolution
War of Liberation (1945-49), after which the Communists 共產黨武裝|共产党武装 under Mao Zedong 毛澤東|毛泽东 took over from the Nationalists 國民政府|国民政府 under Chiang Kai-shek 蔣介石|蒋介石
Liu Shaoqi (1898-1969), Chinese communist leader, a martyr of the Cultural Revolution
Red Army (1928-1937), predecessor of the PLA/(Soviet) Red Army (1917-1946)
base of operations
army and government
He Long (1896-1969), important communist military leader, died from persecution during the Cultural Revolution
New Fourth army of Republic of China, set up in 1937 and controlled by the communists
Hua Guofeng (1921-2008), leader of Chinese Communist Party after the Cultural Revolution
United Front (either of the two alliances between the Guomindang and the Communist Party, 1923-1927 and 1937-1945)
Communist International or Comintern (1919-1943), also known as the Third International 第三國際|第三国际[Di4 san1 Guo2 ji4]
Lushan district of Jiujiang city 九江市, Jiangxi/Mt Lushan in Jiujiang, famous as summer holiday spot
Chinese Nationalist Party 國民黨|国民党[Guo2 min2 dang3] and Chinese Communist Party 共產黨|共产党[Gong4 chan3 dang3]
Zhang Guotao (1897-1979), Chinese communist leader in the 1920s and 1930s, defected to Guomindang in 1938
